attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a physical stock take of raw materials and finished product on 19th February 2025 to determine whether the stocks movement at the Branch was well managed and to assess the effectiveness of existing controls.
  • The items with variances were as stated below:
    • Polybags had a variance of +106 Pieces
    • Finished product had a variance of -67 Loaves.
  • The other raw materials had negligible variances as illustrated:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to increase spot checks and verify recorded yield against actual yield to detect and eliminate or reduce the bread variance.
attributes.effect: • The minimal variances noted imply adequate stock controls at the branch, however the bread shortfall was an indication of lapses in monitoring and verification of actual yield.
attributes.remediation_plan: The branch management to strengthen controls in place to alleviate variances.

value:
• Bread variance was due to wrong record of yield but we are going to be keen going forward to avoid the variation.
  • Recovery was made via deductions.
• Most of the raw materials had nil balances and only bread had the noted variance which was recovered. The branch manager has been advised to check and control stocks shift-wise.

In the prior audit report dated 10th January 2025 stock variances were as seen below :

  • Bread -8 Loaves
  • Polybags +35 pieces
  • Utto +0.41 Kgs/Litres
• The minimal variances noted imply adequate stock controls at the branch, however the bread shortfall was an indication of lapses in monitoring and verification of actual yield.

attributes.title: Bread  Weight
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a spot check on the weights of packed bread on 19th February 2025 to verify if the set bread weight standards were being adhered to.
  • Underweights were noted in 400g CTw(25/75) and 400g BT(11/75) as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to adhere to the set weight ranges and quality standards to ensure compliance to the recommended weight.
attributes.effect: • Presence of underweight bread signified lapses in implementation of the set dough weight for some varieties and also failure to monitor production process flow to ensure minimized chances of overcooled bread.

value: • We are going to increase spot checks on bread weight to avoid underweight bread and also take action on slicers who do not salvage the bread.
• As at now, close monitoring has been put in place to minimize the noted percentage and our aim is to have zero underweight.
•  In the previous audit report, underweights were noted in the 400g W-21%

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An analysis was done on the bread damage levels for both production and market based deformities for  the period 20th January to 18th February 2025 to detect if damage levels were within the set limits.
  • We noted the following:
    • Production bread damages stood at 0.22% of total production which exceeded the set limit of 0.2%.
    • Market damages stood at 0.35% of total sales which was above the set limit of 0.5%.
attributes.recommendation: • Enhance controls within the production process to ensure bread produced is of good quality thereby minimize possibility of excess production damages.
attributes.effect: • The production bread damages exceeded the set damage limits and therefore implied compromised bread quality for the audited period.

value:
• The baking tins used were damaged hence increasing bread damages but we are expecting new baking tins.
  • We will maintain the controls on market damages.
• Pangani tins are due for replacement which contributed to the damages percentage indicated, however, once we are done with the replacement, the production damages should be minimal.
• During the prior audit it was noted that production damages were 0.23% of the total production while market damages were 0.33% of the total sales.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted an analysis of both the mixing chart and mixing chart summaries for the period 20th January to 18th February 2025 to determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.
  • We noted the following:
    • Average yield was 191 loaves per bag
    • Average production was 40.10 bags equivalent to 89% of the set target of 45 bags.
    • Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1
    • No remixes were observed for the reviewed audit period as detailed in the table below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to improve on production target achievement.
attributes.effect: • 89% production target achievement indicated that there was room for improvement.

value: • The target was not achieved due to shift cuts but we will improve.
• The drop in production was mainly contributed by low sales which led to shift cuts since we produce as per the demand order.

·       During the prior audit, the following were noted :

  • Utto usage ratio 100%,

  •   Average yield  191

  •   Average production 40.50 bags.

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • Verification of cash held at the cashier’s office was done on 19th February 2025, to confirm if the cash balances tallied with cash-flow records and whether the set cash operation standards.
  • We noted that there was nil variance, however, there was 1 pending IOUs worth KES 8,000 relating to sewage expenses dated 12/02/2025 that had surpassed the 3-day clearance period.
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to follow up on clearance of pending IOUs.
attributes.effect: • The cash controls were adequate and effective, however, there was need to follow the IOU clearance period policy.

value: • We will maintain and follow up on IOU.
• We will maintain and follow up on IOU.
•   In the prior audit report dated 10th January 2025, it was noted that there was no variance.

attributes.title: Minishop Verification
attributes.description:
Findings.

  •  A spot check on Mini shop was done on 19th February 2025 to determine if all loaded bread was accounted for and if the sales were equivalent to the till  balances given that the mini-shop did not accept physical cash.
  • We noted that all the sales done as at the time of the spot check were accounted for and all the expected bread balances from loading done exclusive of sales were physically available. This was as illustrated below:
attributes.recommendation: • The management should maintain the Mini shop controls.
attributes.effect: • All sales and bread balances were accounted for which indicated that the Mini shop controls were effective.

value: • During  the previous audit dated 10th January 2025, the minishop was well controlled.

attributes.title: Debtors' Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An analysis of the debt balances as at COB 18th February 2025 was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.
  • The findings were as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: •  Follow up on pending balances for clearance.
attributes.effect: • Debt balances were minimal, therefore well controlled, however efforts should be made to recover the pending balances.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a review of the branch’s management of human capital resources availed to the production section to determine if the allocation of production workers was optimal as per the Company’s set standards for the period 20th January to 18th February 2025.
  • We noted that the production efficiency was at 4.85 bags per production worker for the period which surpassed the set standard of 4.3 therefore has a Savings implication of KES 34,771.20.
  • The results were as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • Branch management to uphold the controls and improve further
attributes.effect: • The branch attained and surpassed its target implying efficient allocation of production workers based on planned production.

value: • The previous audit report dated 10th January 2025 indicated a production efficiency of 4.79 bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An assessment was conducted on the utilization of packers in the slicing section to determine if optimality was attained based on the set Company standard of 97 crates per packer.
  •  We noted that, for the period 20th January to 18th February 2025, the packing efficiency stood at 94.05 crates per packer which was below the standard set.
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to ensure optimal allocation of packers based on the set standards.
attributes.effect: • The branch did not attain the set slicing efficiency implying extra cost of KES 4,560 incurred in paying excess 5 workers.

value: • We have noted this and will work towards improving further.
• Going forward, better to excellent results on the efficiency are expected.
• The previous audit report indicated a packing efficiency of 93.99 crates per packer.

attributes.title: Vehicle Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  •  A review was conducted on the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption vis a vis the set standard consumption rate to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period 1st -18th February 2025.
  • We noted that the one route vehicle’s fuel consumption was within the set standard as detailed in Appendix I below:
attributes.recommendation: • Maintain and enhance the fuel management controls within the branch.

value: • During the previous audit dated 10th January 2025, fuel consumption was okay.
